title: My Child Is Afraid of Math – Now What?
description: Practical steps to help a child overcome fear and anxiety around mathematics.
imageAlt: Child looking worried at math problems

content.intro: When your child's eyes well up at the sight of a math worksheet, it's not about being "bad at math." It's fear. And fear can be addressed.

sections.text: Math anxiety is real and documented. Brain imaging shows that math anxiety activates the same regions as physical pain. Your child isn't exaggerating – they're experiencing genuine distress.
Studies estimate 20-25% of students experience moderate to high math anxiety. It's more common than you think.

items: Avoiding math homework ("I forgot" / "I'll do it later")
Crying or tantrums around math time
Negative self-talk ("I'm stupid" / "I can't do this")
Blank mind during tests (knows material but can't access it)
Parents' or teachers' anxiety around math
Messages that "some people aren't math people"

sections.text: Don't dismiss it. "I can see math feels scary for you right now. That's okay. We're going to work on it together." Validation reduces shame.
Temporarily. No timed tests. No public answering. No consequence for wrong answers. Create safety first.
Go back to where they feel confident. Even if it seems "too easy." Success rebuilds confidence. Confidence reduces fear.
If worksheets trigger fear, try apps. If apps trigger fear, try games. If sitting triggers fear, try standing. Change enough that it feels "different."
"Mistakes help your brain grow." "I make mistakes too." "Getting it wrong means you're learning." Say these regularly until they believe it.
"You tried that hard problem!" "You didn't give up!" Effort is always within their control; results aren't.
The goal isn't to make them love math immediately. It's to reduce the fear enough that they can engage. Love (or at least tolerance) can come later.
Consider a psychologist or therapist if:

items: Fear is severe (panic attacks, school refusal)
Your strategies don't help after 2-3 months
There are underlying issues (trauma, anxiety disorder)

faq.question: Is math anxiety genetic?
faq.answer: Not directly, but anxious tendencies can be inherited. More importantly, parents who express math anxiety often transmit it to children.

faq.question: Will they always struggle with math?
faq.answer: No! Math anxiety is treatable. Many students overcome it completely with the right support and experiences.

faq.question: Should I tell the teacher?
faq.answer: Yes. Teachers can make accommodations (extra time, no public calling) that reduce anxiety at school.
